Award.AwardTitle: Accelerated Degradation of Active Nanosystems by Biomolecular Motors

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop an understanding of the degradation pathways of active nanosystems. At the macroscale, a car engine will rust when inactive, but wear out when running. Similarly, active nanosystems which incorporate mechanical motion degrade faster when activated. This project will utilize molecular shuttles, nanoscale transport systems powered by the motor protein kinesin, as a model system. Microfabricated guiding structures will be used to exert defined, cyclic loads on the moving shuttles, and optical microscopy will be employed to observe the breaking of the central part of the shuttle. Investigating degradation within these active
nanostructures explores new ground, since the molecular shuttle system is too large to be readily described in atomic-level terms of force-activated dissociation of single bonds, but too small to apply macroscopic concepts of wear and fatigue. Thus a mesoscale view of these systems on the nanoscale is required and will be developed through a combination of experiment,simulation, and theory.

The result of this research will be an improved understanding of wear and fatigue at the nanoscale. This understanding is on one hand critical for the design of durable devices which can function for their intended lifetime without failure. On the other hand, degradation products may be released from the system, similar to the ?brake dust? created from brake pads in a car. To assess the potential environmental and toxicological impact of active nanosystems it is therefore important to understand how the nanosystem evolves over its lifetime and ultimately fails. While this research is only a first step towards understanding these complex processes, it will ? if successful ? create a template for the evaluation of other active nanosystems and provide a basic scientific framework to understand these degradation processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Degradation as a result of mechanical activity is a familiar process in everyday life. For example, a car engine degrades by rusting away if it sits around for an extended amount of time, while it wears out much faster when operating. Similarly, one could suspect that nanomachines and mechanically active nanostructures also wear out faster if they are in operation. We studied for the first time the degradation of one such mechanically active nanostructure: molecular shuttles powered by kinesin motor proteins. These nanoscale transport systems consist of surface-adhered nanosteppers (the kinesin motors) which push a cargo-carrying microtubule. Using extremely sensitive length measurements, we found that the microtubule shrinks slowly when the kinesin motors are inactive, and up to seven times faster when the kinesin motors are active. That means the saying “It is not the age, it is the mileage” is also true in the nanoworld. We further looked at what precisely influenced the shrinking, and found that the number of motors attached at the same time to the microtubule and also the velocity of the gliding matter. Our investigations also led us to new insights about what it means to make good use of a molecular bond, and we found that the kinesin motors change their shape when they are placed close together.

Our ideas and findings were described in four publications, one graduate student received a Ph.D. for his work on the project, and several undergraduate students were introduced to Science and Engineering. Two of those students already decided to pursue careers in engineering and are now enrolled in Engineering Ph.D. programs. The principal investigator also mentored student teams who participated successfully at the annual Biomod Biomolecular Design Competition at the Wyss Institute at Harvard University.
